choices.text: Take 2 pills the same day and continue
Continue pills and take extra precaution for 1 week

questions.text: A 23y woman who is using the combined oral contraceptive pill misses 2 pills in the 3rd week of the pack. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Take 2 pills the same day and continue

 

Explanation:

 

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, the missed pill guidelines are –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure and continue the packet: Simply continuing the packet without taking the missed pills would increase the risk of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Continue pills and take extra precaution for 1 week: This option is more applicable for missing three or more pills, where additional precautions and possibly emergency contraception might be necessary.

 

Option D. Start a new packet immediately: This approach is necessary only when three or more pills are missed in the third week, to avoid a pill-free interval and ensure continued contraceptive protection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If one or two combined oral contraceptive pills are missed in the third week, the woman should take the last missed pill as soon as possible, then continue the pack as scheduled, taking two pills in one day if necessary. This minimizes the risk of pregnancy.

questions.text: LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section) for breech was done. Intraoperatively, this was seen. Two cervixes were also identified. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine didelphys

 

Uterine didelphys is a congenital uterine anomaly characterized by the presence of two separate uterine cavities, each with its own cervix, due to the failure of the Müllerian ducts to fuse during fetal development. The presence of two cervices identified intraoperatively strongly indicates uterine didelphys, where each cervix is associated with its own uterine body.

 

In the image, the appearance of two distinctly separate uterine bodies confirms the diagnosis. One uterus appears larger because it likely accommodated the pregnancy, while the other uterus remains smaller. This anomaly often presents during procedures like cesarean sections, where the characteristic appearance of two separate uterine structures is noted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arcuate uterus: This is a mild form of uterine anomaly characterized by a slight indentation at the top of the uterine cavity. It does not present with two separate uterine bodies or two cervices.

 

Option B. Bicornuate uterus: This condition features a single cervix with a heart-shaped uterine cavity, partially divided into two horns. It does not have two completely separate uterine bodies or cervices.

 

Option C. Unicornuate uterus: This anomaly is characterized by a single uterine horn with only one cervix, often associated with a rudimentary horn. It does not present as two separate uterine structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterine didelphys is characterized by two separate uterine cavities, each with its own cervix, due to a failure of Müllerian duct fusion during fetal development.

questions.text: The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Y chromosome

 

Explanation:

 

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, specifically the SRY gene located on the short arm of the Y chromosome. The SRY gene produces testis-determining factor (TDF), which induces the development of the bipotential gonads into testes. The Sertoli cells in the testes secrete Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH), which causes regression of the Mullerian ducts, structures that would otherwise develop into female internal genitalia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, specifically the SRY gene, which leads to the secretion of Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) by the Sertoli cells and regression of the Mullerian ducts in males.

choices.text: Vitamin B12 deficiency
Folate deficiency
Pyridoxine deficiency

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the classic causes of megaloblastic anemia.

 

 

Pernicious anemia is a type of megaloblastic anemia caused by autoimmune gastritis and an inability to produce intrinsic factors, resulting in vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Histologically, there is chronic atrophic gastritis with parietal cell loss, a prominent infiltrate of lymphocytes and plasma cells, and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells similar to those seen in erythroid precursors.

 

There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:

 

  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intrinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the a and B subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Folate deficiency: Folate deficiency also causes megaloblastic anemia with macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils but is not typically associated with atrophic gastritis.

 

  • Folate deficiency does not usually present with the same gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting) or the autoimmune component seen in pernicious anemia.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine deficiency: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency is associated with sideroblastic anemia, not megaloblastic anemia.

 

  • It does not cause macrocytic anemia or atrophic gastritis.

 

Option D. Niacin deficiency: Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by the "4 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and death.

 

  • It does not cause macrocytic anemia or atrophic gastritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency, often due to pernicious anemia, is characterized by macrocytic anemia, hypersegmented neutrophils, and atrophic gastritis. This condition involves an autoimmune mechanism that impairs the production and function of intrinsic factor, essential for vitamin B12 absorption.

questions.text: MRI rooms are shielded from electromagnetic radiations by: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Faraday cage

 

Explanation:

 

MRI rooms are shielded using Faraday cages, which are enclosures formed by conductive material that block external electromagnetic fields. This shielding is essential because MRI scanners are extremely sensitive to external electromagnetic interference, which would otherwise degrade image quality. The Faraday cage prevents external RF signals from entering the MRI environment while also containing the RF signals generated by the MRI scanner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maxwell cage - This is not a recognized term in electromagnetic shielding technology. While James Clerk Maxwell developed fundamental equations of electromagnetism that underlie MRI physics, there is no shielding structure called a "Maxwell cage."

 

Option C. Edison's cage - This is an incorrect term. Thomas Edison has no electromagnetic shielding structure named after him in MRI or medical imaging technology.

 

Option D. Ohm's cage - This is not a valid term in electromagnetic shielding. Georg Ohm is known for Ohm's law relating to electrical circuits, but there is no "Ohm's cage" used in MRI technology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Faraday cage principle is fundamental to MRI technology, providing the necessary electromagnetic isolation that allows these sensitive imaging devices to function properly in environments filled with electromagnetic interference.

questions.text: The X-ray of a 5-year-old child is given below. Clinical examination, and hematological and urinary tests were normal. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

  • The history and the provided imaging, which shows a single punched-out lytic lesion without a sclerotic rim and with a beveled edge look, point to Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).
  • LCH is a rare disorder involving clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells, abnormal cells deriving from bone marrow and capable of migrating from skin to lymph nodes. This condition particularly affects children and can present with single or multiple lytic bone lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma:  A diagnosis of multiple myeloma is made by the typical triad of symptoms, which includes a marrow plasmacytosis of more than 10%, radiologic evidence of lytic bone lesions, and the presence of serum and/or urine M component.

 

 

Option C. Metastasis: In children, metastatic lesions in the skull are uncommon and typically originate from primary neuroblastoma or sarcoma but would present with different clinical features and possibly multiple lesions.


Option D. Primary hyperparathyroidism:  Patients with this condition have high levels of the parathyroid hormone, as well as hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypercalciuria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis is the most probable diagnosis given the age of the child, the radiographic appearance of the skull lesion, and the absence of systemic symptoms or biochemical abnormalities typically associated with the other conditions listed.

questions.text: Auenbrugger’s sign is seen in: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pericardial Effusion

 

Explanation:

 

Auenbrugger's sign refers to dullness in the left posterior lung field (at the base) that is seen in patients with large pericardial effusions. This is also known as Ewart's sign. When the pericardium expands due to fluid accumulation, it causes minicollapse and dullness in the left posterior lung field, which can be detected on percussion examination. This physical finding is characteristic of significant pericardial effusions.

 

 Other Options: 

 

Option B. Constrictive Pericarditis: Constrictive pericarditis presents with signs of right heart failure, increased JVP with prominent x and y descent, pericardial knock, and Kussmaul's sign (no respiratory variation of JVP). Auenbrugger's sign is not a feature of constrictive pericarditis.

 

Option C. Aortic Regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation typically presents with wide pulse pressure, diastolic murmur, and signs of left ventricular volume overload. Auenbrugger's sign is not associated with this valvular condition.

 

Option D. Mitral Stenosis: Mitral stenosis typically presents with symptoms of pulmonary congestion, a diastolic murmur, and possible atrial fibrillation. Auenbrugger's sign is not a feature of mitral stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auenbrugger's sign (also known as Ewart's sign) is a physical finding characterized by dullness in the left posterior lung field due to compression by an enlarged pericardium in patients with large pericardial effusions.

choices.text: Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease
Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease
Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease
All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.text: Numerous youngsters from a specific community arrived at a medical facility and were diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the water of that community. If a case-control investigation were to be conducted to find the potential association between the chemical waste and ALL, what would serve as the control group? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease

 

Case control study: A study that compares patients who have a disease or outcome of interest (cases) with patients who do not have the disease or outcome (controls), and looks back retrospectively to compare how frequently the exposure to a risk factor is present in each group to determine the relationship between the risk factor and the disease

 

In a case control study, we never try to match the actual risk factor under study

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case-control study investigating the association between chemical waste exposure and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the control group should consist of children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease (ALL). This ensures a proper baseline for comparison to identify potential risk factors associated with the disease.

questions.text: A lot of patients presented to PHC OPD with edema, ocular problems, cardiac failure. Several deaths were reported too. There was a common history of buying oil from a local grocery store. Drug inspector will use the following test to detect adulteration. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Paper chromatography test

 

The condition described in the question is epidemic dropsy, which is caused by the consumption of mustard oil adulterated with Argemone Mexicana oil. The toxic component of Argemone oil is Sanguinarine, a potent toxin that inhibits the oxidation of pyruvic acid, leading to symptoms such as bilateral non-inflammatory edema, glaucoma, congestive heart failure, and even death.

 

Paper chromatography test is the most sensitive method to detect Argemone oil adulteration in mustard oil, even at extremely low concentrations (0.0001%). This test identifies the presence of Sanguinarine, thus confirming the contamination of the mustard oil with Argemone oil.

 

Other test is - Nitric acid test shows an orange-brown discoloration if Argemone oil is present, requiring a concentration of 0.25% for a positive result.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nitrate test: This option is incorrect. The nitrate test is commonly employed to detect nitrates in water, food, or soil.

 

Option B. Phosphatase test:  This option is incorrect. The phosphatase test is used primarily to determine the pasteurization status of milk, not for detecting oil adulteration.

 

Option D. Sulphuric acid test: This option is incorrect. While sulphuric acid can be used in various tests, it is not the specific test for detecting Argemone oil adulteration in mustard oil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidemic dropsy is caused by the consumption of mustard oil adulterated with Argemone Mexicana oil, and the most sensitive test for detecting this adulteration is the paper chromatography test.

questions.text: Rachitic rosary is seen with which deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Rachitic rosary is a classic finding in rickets, a condition caused by Vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D is essential for calcium absorption and bone mineralization, and its deficiency leads to impaired bone growth and mineralization, resulting in features like rachitic rosary. The prominence of the costochondral junctions, referred to as rachitic rosary, is due to impaired bone mineralization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Rachitic rosary is not associated with Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A deficiency primarily leads to impaired vision (night blindness), dry skin, and immune system issues.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy, primarily manifests with symptoms such as bleeding gums, petechiae, and impaired wound healing. Rachitic rosary is not associated with Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency primarily leads to bleeding disorders due to impaired blood clotting, but it is not associated with rachitic rosary. Vitamin K deficiency does not affect bone mineralization in the same way as Vitamin D deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rachitic rosary is a classic finding in rickets, a condition caused by Vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for diagnosis of which of the following condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxoplasmosis

 

Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis.

 

It is based on the principle that the presence of anti-toxoplasma antibodies in the patient's serum inhibits the staining of trophozoites by alkaline methylene blue dye.

 

Toxoplasma trophozoites and complement are added to the patient's serum which is then incubated for an hour at 37°C. After incubation, methylene blue dye is added.

 

If anti-toxoplasma antibodies are present in the serum, these are activated by complement and the parasite membrane is lysed. Thus, the trophozoites are not stained (positive result).

 

If there are no antibodies, trophozoites will take up the stain and appear blue under the microscope. This is considered to be a negative result.

 

The dilution of the test serum at which 50% of the tachyoites are not stained is reported as the antibody titer of the test serum. The test is highly sensitive and specific.

 

It cannot differentiate between recent or past infections as it detects only IgG antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paragonimiasis: Incorrect, as the Sabin-Feldman dye test is not used for diagnosing Paragonimiasis.

 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Incorrect, the diagnosis of hydatid disease is primarily performed using imaging techniques and the Casoni skin test.

 

Option D. Cryptococcus: Incorrect, Cryptococcus infections are typically diagnosed using fungal cultures and cryptococcal antigen tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sabin-Feldman dye test remains a gold standard for the serological diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis due to its ability to detect the presence of specific antibodies against Toxoplasma gondii, reflecting the body's immune response to the infection.

 

Additional Information

 

Skin test for diagnosis of parasitic infections:

 

  1. Casoni test – Hydatid disease
  2. Montenegro test – Kala azar
  3. Frenkel test – Toxoplasmosis
  4. Fairley test – Schistosomiasis
  5. Bachman test – Trichinellosis

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in asbestosis except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Emphysema

 

Explanation:

 

Asbestosis is characterized by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis with specific histologic and gross features that do not include emphysema. The hallmark pathologic findings in asbestosis include diffuse interstitial fibrosis that predominantly affects the lower lobes and subpleural regions. This fibrosis is associated with the presence of asbestos bodies (golden-brown, fusiform or beaded rods with a translucent center) formed when macrophages attempt to phagocytose asbestos fibers. Additionally, pleural involvement is common, manifesting as pleural plaques, diffuse pleural thickening, and calcific pleural plaques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis - This is correct for asbestosis. The disease causes progressive interstitial fibrosis of the lungs that begins in the lower lobes and subpleural regions and extends to involve the middle and upper lobes as fibrosis progresses.

 

Option B. Fibrous pleural thickening - This is a characteristic feature of asbestosis. Fibrosis develops in the visceral pleura, causing adhesions between the lungs and chest wall.

 

Option D. Calcific pleural plaques - These are common manifestations of asbestos exposure. They consist of well-circumscribed plaques of dense collagen, often containing calcium, that develop most frequently on the parietal pleura and diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Asbestosis is characterized by diffuse interstitial pulmonary fibrosis, pleural plaques (often calcified), and pleural thickening, but not emphysema, which is a distinct pathologic process involving destruction of alveolar walls predominantly associated with smoking and alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

choices.text: Subthalamic nuclei
Globus pallidus

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffered from a stroke 2 days ago. He now presents with involuntary, violent, and flinging movements of the limbs on one side. What is the likely site of lesion in this patient?   (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subthalamic nuclei

 

Explanation

 

Most probable diagnosis as per the clinical history is hemiballismus which is caused by a lesion in subthalamic nuclei.

 

Hemiballismus is a disorder characterized by violent involuntary abnormal movements on one side of the body involving mostly the arm. While walking, the arm swings widely. These movements are called the flinging movements. These movements are due to the release phenomenon because of the absence of inhibitory influence on movements. Hemiballismus occurs due to degeneration of subthalamic nucleus of Luys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Globus pallidus: Incorrect for hemiballismus. Lesions here typically result in different forms of dyskinesia, such as parkinsonism or dystonia, but not hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Putamen: Also incorrect for this symptom. While putamen lesions are involved in many movement disorders, like Huntington's disease and some forms of Parkinson's disease, they do not typically cause hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Caudate nucleus: Incorrect. Lesions in the caudate nucleus are more often associated with Huntington's disease, which leads to chorea—rapid, jerky movements—not the large-amplitude flinging movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with unilateral flinging, violent limb movements following a stroke, the subthalamic nuclei should be considered as the primary site of lesion. This knowledge is crucial for accurate diagnosis and guiding treatment decisions, such as the use of neuroleptics or other interventions to control these disruptive movements.

questions.text: A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rickettsia prowazekii

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic or louse-borne typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

 

Pediculus corporis (human body louse) is the vector for the parasite, although the head louse may also transmit the disease. After the incubation period of 5 - 15 days, the disease typically starts with fever and chills. By around 4 - 5th day of fever, a characteristic rash appears, which starts on the trunk and spreads over the limbs but spares the face, palms, and soles.

 

The infection can be transmitted by

 

  • Contaminated louse feces rubbed through abrasions caused by scratching
  • Inhalation of aerosols of dried louse feces or directly through the conjunctiva

 

The disease is often severe with the fever lasting for over 2 weeks and is more fatal in patients older than 40 years of age.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia typhi causes murine (flea-borne) or endemic typhus. Rats are the reservoirs of infection and the parasite is transmitted by Xenopsylla cheopis (flea). The infection is transmitted when the flea feces is rubbed into the bite wound. The clinical features are similar to that of epidemic typhus but are milder and rarely fatal.

 

Patients can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Rickettsia akari causes rickettsial pox, which is a mild disease resembling varicella. The disease is transmitted by mites and the patients may present with fever, headache, and a vesicular rash.

 

Option D. Rickettsia conorii causes the Mediterranean spotted fever. The parasite is transmitted by ticks and the patients present with fever, headache, rash, and eschar (tache noire).

 

Educational Objective

 

Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted by body lice, causes epidemic typhus, which is characterized by a rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities while sparing the face, palms, and soles. Awareness of this disease's clinical features and transmission methods is essential for preventing outbreaks in high-risk environments.

questions.text: Fracture at which site in leg will cause failure of dorsiflexion of foot? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proximal fibular neck

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • Trauma to the proximal neck of fibula leads to injury of the common peroneal nerve as the nerve winds around the neck of fibula.
  • The CPN injury causes paralysis of muscles of anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, namely tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus and brevis, EHL, peroneus tertius (deep peroneal nerve), peroneal longus and brevis (superficial peroneal nerve).
  • Paralysis of these muscles causes failure of foot dorsiflexion i.e., foot drop.

 

 

  • There is also sensory loss on the anterior and lateral sides of the leg, dorsum of the foot and toes, and medial side of the big toe.
  • Lateral border of the foot and lateral side of the little toe are unaffected (supplied by sural nerve, formed by tibial nerve).
  • Medial border of the foot and ball of big toe are also unaffected (supplied by saphenous nerve, branch of femoral nerve).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral malleolus: Fracture at the lateral malleolus is Danis-Weber type A fracture of the ankle. In this, there is fracture of the lateral malleolus distal to the syndesmosis. It is usually a stable fracture. It is generally below the tibial plafond, with an intact syndesmosis and deltoid ligament. This fracture does not cause any nerve injury; thus no ankle movement is affected. This fracture has a good prognosis with ankle secured in a splint or cast.

 

Option B. Proximal tibia: Fracture of proximal third of tibia is associated with anterior knee pain (cases operated with intramedullary nailing), non-union, malunion. No nerve is injured with this type of fracture.

 

Option D. Tibial shaft: Tibial shaft fractures rarely cause nerve injury. Surgical fixation of the fracture with plating puts the superficial peroneal nerve at risk. Saphenous nerve can be injured during placement of locking screws. Transient peroneal nerve palsy after closed nailing can cause EHL weakness and decreased sensation of first dorsal webspace.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the proximal neck of fibula causes paralysis of dorsiflexion of the foot because around this portion, the common peroneal nerve winds, which supplies the dorsiflexors of the foot.

questions.text: What is the cut-off score for defining Severe Acute Pancreatitis from below? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. APACHE II Score > 8

 

Explanation:

 

Several prognostic scoring systems are used to predict severity in acute pancreatitis. The threshold for severe pancreatitis using the APACHE II scoring system is >8. This score helps clinicians identify patients at higher risk of complications who may require intensive monitoring and aggressive management. Severity stratification is particularly important to determine which patients might develop persistent organ failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ranson Score >1 - INCORRECT The Ranson score threshold for severe acute pancreatitis is ≥3 (not >1). This score is assessed at admission and 48 hours later, with criteria including age, white blood cell count, blood glucose, LDH, and AST initially, followed by hematocrit fall, BUN rise, calcium levels, and other parameters at 48 hours.

 

Option B. Imrie Score > 6 - INCORRECT The Imrie score (Glasgow score) defines severe pancreatitis as ≥3 criteria present, not >6. The Glasgow criteria include 8 parameters total, similar to the Ranson criteria but assessed at different timepoints.

 

Option D. ROME Score > 3 - INCORRECT The ROME Score is not a validated or recognized scoring system for acute pancreatitis severity assessment. The primary scoring systems used in clinical practice include Ranson, Glasgow, APACHE II, BISAP, and modified Marshall scoring systems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute pancreatitis is defined by persistent organ failure (>48 hours) and can be predicted using several scoring systems, with APACHE II score >8 being an important threshold for identifying high-risk patients.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition from the given graph. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive

 

The graph shown is a Lineweaver-Burk plot, which is a double reciprocal plot commonly used to illustrate enzyme kinetics. In this plot, the x-axis represents the reciprocal of the substrate concentration (1/[S]), and the y-axis represents the reciprocal of the reaction velocity (1/V). The graph is particularly useful in distinguishing different types of enzyme inhibition.

 

In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme. This type of inhibition is characterized by an increase in the apparent Km (Michaelis constant), which is reflected as a change in the slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot. However, the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged because the effect of the inhibitor can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration.

 

In the Lineweaver-Burk plot, this is depicted as the two lines (with and without inhibitor) crossing at the y-axis. The y-intercept remains the same (indicating unchanged Vmax), but the slope changes due to the increase in apparent Km, which shifts the x-intercept closer to the origin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-competitive: In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, not the active site. This binding reduces the overall number of active enzyme molecules, thereby decreasing Vmax without affecting Km. In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, this results in lines that intersect on the x-axis, not the y-axis.

 

 

Option C. Un-competitive: Un-competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to the free enzyme. This results in parallel lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, as both Km and Vmax decrease.

 

 

Option D. Allosteric: Allosteric inhibition involves the binding of an inhibitor to a site other than the active site, leading to changes in enzyme activity. This type of inhibition is more complex and isn't typically represented by a Lineweaver-Burk plot in the same way competitive, non-competitive, or un-competitive inhibitions are.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In competitive inhibition, the Lineweaver-Burk plot shows lines that cross at the y-axis, indicating that Vmax remains unchanged while Km increases due to the competition between the inhibitor and the substrate for the enzyme's active site.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs can increase glucose excretion in urine? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Empagliflozin

 

Explanation:

 

Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor.

 

Drugs in this class (such as empagliflozin, canagliflozin, and dapagliflozin) inhibit the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine (glycosuria). This helps lower blood glucose levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glimepiride: A sulfonylurea that stimulates insulin release from the pancreas.

 

Option B. Liraglutide: A GLP-1 receptor agonist that increases insulin secretion, slows gastric emptying, and promotes satiety.

 

Option C. Acarbose: An alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays carbohydrate absorption in the intestines, leading to increased excretion of undigested carbohydrates in the stools.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, increases glucose excretion in the urine by inhibiting the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in the kidneys.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • ﻿﻿They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • ﻿﻿It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

 

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

 

In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

 

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm.

 

Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection, characterized by eggs that are oval and thin-shelled, different from the barrel-shaped eggs of whipworm.

 

Option C. Necator americanus: Another species of hookworm with similar egg morphology to Ancylostoma duodenale.

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: Causes ascariasis and is characterized by larger, oval, and thick-shelled eggs, distinct from the eggs of whipworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the distinctive egg morphology of Trichuris trichiura in stool samples is crucial for diagnosing whipworm infection. Proper sanitation and hygiene are key in preventing soil-transmitted helminth infections, and treatment involves specific antihelminthic medications to reduce the worm burden and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: In Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND), which of the following structures is not preserved? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Submandibular gland 

 

In a Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND), the goal is to remove lymphatic tissue that may contain cancer while preserving as many structures as possible to reduce morbidity. 

 

Option A. Sternocleidomastoid muscle: In an MRND, this muscle is typically preserved unless it is involved with the tumor.

 

Option B. Internal jugular vein: This vein is usually preserved in an MRND to maintain venous drainage from the head, unless it is involved with the tumor.

 

Option C. Spinal accessory nerve: Preservation of the spinal accessory nerve is a key goal in MRND to prevent shoulder dysfunction that can occur if the nerve is sacrificed.

 

Option D. Submandibular gland: The submandibular gland is routinely removed in an MRND, especially if the lymph nodes closely associated with it are involved with malignant disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In Modified Radical Neck Dissection, the sternocleidomastoid muscle, internal jugular vein, and spinal accessory nerve are typically preserved to reduce morbidity, while the submandibular gland is often removed due to its close association with lymphatic structures that are at risk for malignancy.

questions.text: Common precursor amino acid for urea, creatine and nitric oxide is? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arginine

 

Arginine is the common precursor for urea, creatine and nitric oxide.

 

Arginine serves as the common precursor for all three compounds. It plays a central role in the urea cycle, where it is converted into ornithine, eventually leading to the production of urea. Additionally, arginine is a precursor for creatine synthesis, which is important for energy metabolism in muscles. It is also a precursor for nitric oxide, which has various physiological functions, including vasodilation and neurotransmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycine: Glycine is not the common precursor for these three compounds. It is involved in various metabolic pathways but not directly related to the synthesis of urea, creatine, or nitric oxide.

 

Option C. Aspartate: Aspartate is not the common precursor for urea, creatine, and nitric oxide. It is primarily involved in the urea cycle as a component of reactions leading to the synthesis of arginine and urea.

 

Option D. Alanine: Alanine is not the common precursor for these compounds. It has roles in various metabolic pathways, but it is not directly involved in the synthesis of urea, creatine, or nitric oxide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ornithine and citrulline are derivatives of arginine, and are essential for urea synthesis.
  • Creatine is synthesized from 3 amino acids: glycine, arginine and methionine (GAME)
  • Arginine is the precursor of nitric oxide which is an important signal molecule in the body.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a 6-year-old child whose head and neck was burnt in an accident at school? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18%

 

As per Lund and Browder chart the percentage of burns in this child would be 18%.

 

For the 1-9 years age group, the Lund-Browder chart is divided into the following regions:

 

  1. Head and Neck: 18%
  2. Anterior Trunk: 18%
  3. Posterior Trunk: 18%
  4. Each Arm: 9%
  5. Each Leg: 14%
  6. Perineum: 1%

 

The Lund-Browder chart is a tool used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) of burns in paediatric patients. It is divided into regions that correspond to different percentages of TBSA, and each region is assigned a different percentage based on the age of the patient. The chart takes into account the fact that the proportion of body surface area represented by different body parts changes as a child grows.

 

The chart is divided into three age groups: 0-1 year, 1-9 years, and 9-17 years. Each age group has its own chart with different regions and percentages. The regions are further divided into sub-regions to allow for more accurate estimation of the TBSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9%: For a 6-year-old child, 9% represents the TBSA of each arm. This does not correspond to the head and neck region.

 

Option C. 27%: There is no single region in the Lund-Browder chart for the 1-9 years age group that accounts for 27% of the TBSA. The head and neck alone are 18%.

 

Option D. 36%: This percentage does not correspond to any single region or combination of the head and neck in the Lund-Browder chart for a child of this age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the Lund and Browder chart is essential for accurately assessing burn injuries in pediatric patients.
  • For children aged 1-9 years, the head and neck region accounts for 18% of the TBSA.
  • This knowledge is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and management of burn injuries in children.

choices.text: Compression of the inferior vena cava
Compression of the superior vena cava

questions.text: A pregnant woman has dizziness on lying down straight and this improves when she turns to one side. A possible explanation is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Compression of the inferior vena cava

 

Explanation:

 

The scenario described is characteristic of supine hypotensive syndrome, which occurs when a pregnant woman lies flat on her back, causing the gravid uterus to compress the inferior vena cava (IVC). This compression decreases venous return to the heart, leading to reduced cardiac output and subsequent hypotension and dizziness.

 

Symptoms of dizziness and hypotension improve when the woman turns to her side (Left tilt), relieving the compression on the IVC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Compression of the aorta: While the aorta can also be compressed, the primary issue in supine hypotensive syndrome is the reduced venous return due to IVC compression.

 

Option C. Compression of the superior vena cava: This is less likely to be affected by the position of the uterus during pregnancy.
 

Option D. Compression of the pulmonary vessels: This is not typically related to positional changes during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine hypotensive syndrome is caused by the compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus when a pregnant woman lies flat on her back. This condition is relieved by turning to one side, which reduces the compression and improves venous return to the heart.

questions.text: Shown in image is an orthopedic procedure being performed. Identity the procedure? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intraosseous cannulation for fluid therapy

 

INTRAOSSEOUS THERAPY 

 

  • Intraosseous access is a rapid and effective method to deliver fluids, medications, and blood products directly into the bone marrow when intravenous access is difficult or impossible, especially in emergency situations.
  • Interosseous therapy is most commonly used in pediatric patients but can also be used in adults. 
  • The procedure involves inserting a needle or catheter through the skin and into the bone, typically in the tibia or humerus bones.
  • A needle is inserted at 90° to the medial surface of the tibia, and it is connected to a tube, suggesting fluid administration or aspiration.
  • Some common indications for IO therapy include:
    • Cardiac arrest or other life-threatening emergencies
    • Severe dehydration or shock
    • Patients with difficult venous access, such as obese or severely dehydrated patients or patients with vascular access issues due to scarring, burns, or other injuries.
    • Emergency situations such as during disasters or mass casualty incidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intraosseous abscess drainage: A drainage procedure usually involves a larger incision or different type of instrument for effective drainage.


Option C. Diagnostic biopsy: A bone biopsy involves taking a tissue sample for pathological examination. While a needle is used, the setup with continuous tubing for fluid administration is not typical for a routine diagnostic biopsy.
 

Option D. Intraosseous cannulation for pain relief: Intraosseous (IO) cannulation is a rapid method to administer medications through the bone marrow cavity in a critically ill or an injured patient. The procedure is both safe and effective in children and adults. The preferred site for the creation of intraosseous (IO) access is usually the shin. A local anesthetic is injected into the shin. Next, a cannula is inserted into the shin until a popping sensation is felt. Once the attempt is successful, the cannula is connected to the intravenous (IV) infusion set, which is a collection of sterile devices designed to conduct fluids from the IV fluid container to a patient's venous system. Indications for IO access includes arrhythmias, severe haemorrhage, septic shock, respiratory failure, severe dehydration, diabetic ketoacidosis, and burns. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraosseous access for fluid therapy is an orthopedic procedure done in pediatric patients to provide fluid therapy.

questions.text: What is the optimal peak negative pressure to be achieved during vacuum-assisted delivery? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.8 kg/cm²

 

The optimal peak negative pressure to be achieved during vacuum-assisted delivery is 0.8 kg/cm² (608 mm Hg). This pressure is created gradually at a rate of 0.1 kg/cm² per minute over about 10 minutes. Some practitioners may use a rapid negative pressure technique, starting with 0.2 kg/cm² induced slowly over at least 2 minutes, and then increasing to the effective vacuum of 0.8 kg/cm². This level of pressure creates sufficient suction to form the artificial caput succedaneum (chignon) needed for proper traction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1.2 kg/cm²: This pressure is too high and exceeds the recommended peak negative pressure for vacuum extraction. Using excessive pressure would substantially increase the risk of fetal trauma including cephalhematoma, subgaleal hemorrhage, and intracranial bleeding.

 

Option B. 0.2 kg/cm²: This represents only the initial pressure used at the beginning of the procedure. It is insufficient for effective traction and delivery. This low pressure would not create adequate chignon formation or provide sufficient traction force.

 

Option D. 1 kg/cm²: This pressure exceeds the recommended peak negative pressure of 0.8 kg/cm². Higher pressure increases the risk of cup detachment ("pop-offs") and various fetal scalp injuries, without providing additional benefits for delivery.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The optimal peak negative pressure for vacuum-assisted delivery is 0.8 kg/cm² (608 mm Hg), which provides the ideal balance between sufficient traction force and minimal risk of maternal and fetal complications.

choices.text: Infectious Mononucleosis
CMV infection

questions.text: The following cells seen in the lymph node are indicative of: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Measles

 

The pathognomonic slide for measles is presented. A Warthin-Finkeldey giant cell with sizable clusters of inclusion bodies that resemble grapes may be seen on this image of a lymph node biopsy.

 

The Warthin-Finkeldey cells, which are randomly distributed multinucleate giant cells with eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies, massive germinal centres, and noticeable follicular hyperplasia are typical features of lymphoid organs.

 

These are pathognomonic of measles and are also found in the lung and sputum. Kimura illness, measles, lymph nodes in HIV+ people, and other disorders are frequently associated with Warthin-Finkeldey type polykaryocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infectious Mononucleosis: This condition typically shows atypical lymphocytes, not multinucleate giant cells with inclusion bodies.

 

Option C. CMV infection: CMV infections lead to the formation of "owl's eye" inclusion bodies predominantly in cells, different from the grape-like clusters seen in measles.

 

Option D. Influenza: Influenza primarily affects the respiratory epithelium and does not lead to the formation of multinucleate giant cells in lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells with eosinophilic inclusion bodies resembling grape clusters in a lymph node biopsy is pathognomonic of measles.

questions.text: Alzheimer type II astrocytes are not typically found in: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Alzheimer’s disease

 

Explanation: 

 

Alzheimer type II astrocytes are not found in Alzheimer's disease, despite the confusing similarity in names. These specialized astrocytes are characterized by enlarged, pale nuclei with prominent nucleoli and margination of chromatin. They develop in response to metabolic insults, particularly hyperammonemia. Alzheimer's disease instead shows neurofibrillary tangles, amyloid plaques, and neuritic plaques as its characteristic pathological findings, along with diffuse cerebral atrophy affecting the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatic encephalopathy - This condition is characterized by the presence of Alzheimer type II astrocytes. These astrocytic changes occur in response to elevated ammonia levels that cannot be properly metabolized due to liver dysfunction, resulting in cerebral toxicity.

 

Option C. Wilson's Disease - This inherited disorder of copper metabolism affects both the liver and brain. The liver damage leads to increased ammonia levels, which can cause formation of Alzheimer type II astrocytes in the brain as a secondary phenomenon.

 

Option D. Urea Cycle Disorders - These genetic disorders impair the body's ability to eliminate ammonia, leading to hyperammonemia. The elevated ammonia affects the brain and causes the development of Alzheimer type II astrocytes as a pathological response.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Despite their name, Alzheimer type II astrocytes are not found in Alzheimer's disease but are instead characteristic of metabolic encephalopathies associated with hyperammonemia, such as hepatic encephalopathy, Wilson's disease, and urea cycle disorders.

questions.text: Enzyme defect in McArdle’s Disease?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myophosphorylase

 

This is the correct answer. McArdle's Disease results from a deficiency of myophosphorylase, which is an enzyme responsible for breaking down glycogen into glucose within muscle cells. The lack of myophosphorylase impairs the ability of muscle cells to release glucose from glycogen during physical activity, leading to muscle fatigue, pain, and other symptoms typically observed in McArdle's Disease patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose-6-phosphatase: This enzyme is involved in glucose metabolism in the liver, not in muscle cells. Deficiencies in glucose-6-phosphatase lead to other types of Glycogen Storage Diseases, such as Von Gierke's Disease (GSD Ia).

 

Option C. Glycogen synthase : While this enzyme plays a role in glycogen metabolism, it is not the enzyme affected in McArdle's Disease. Instead, it is myophosphorylase that is deficient in this condition.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is involved in the initial steps of glucose metabolism but is not directly related to glycogen breakdown or McArdle's Disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McArdle's disease is Type V glycogen storage disease that occurs due to deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase (Myophosphorylase) enzyme. In this disease, muscle glycogen cannot be used during exercise, so, on strenuous exercise there are muscles cramps. Also, normal or relatively low levels of lactate will be formed from muscle glycogen after exercise.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 167

questions.text: A newborn is delivered with the defect seen in the image below. Identify the condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

 

Omphalocele is characterized by the presence of a sac enclosing the protruding abdominal organs, which herniate into the base of the umbilical cord.

 

The image depicts a newborn with a congenital abdominal wall defect characterized by the protrusion of abdominal organs into the base of the umbilical cord, covered by a sac composed of peritoneum and amniotic membranes. This condition is known as an omphalocele.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastroschisis: Gastroschisis is a congenital defect where the intestines protrude through a hole in the abdominal wall, typically to the right of the umbilicus. Unlike omphalocele, in gastroschisis, the intestines are not covered by a sac and are exposed directly to the amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Persistent vitellointestinal duct: Persistent vitellointestinal duct refers to a remnant of the yolk stalk (vitelline duct) that can cause various intestinal anomalies but does not present as a protrusion of abdominal contents covered by a sac.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal organs protrude into the base of the umbilical cord and are covered by a sac composed of peritoneum and amniotic membranes.

questions.text: Under MTP Act of India, for cases of MTP after 24 weeks POG, there has to be a Medical board to advise. It comprises of all except: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Legal advisor


Under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act of India, a Medical Board must be constituted for termination of pregnancy beyond 24 weeks, specifically in cases of substantial fetal anomalies. This board plays a crucial role in evaluating the circumstances and approving the procedure when necessary. The Medical Board is required to have specific members to provide expert medical advice, including:

 

  1. An Obstetrician-Gynaecologist who provides expertise on maternal and fetal health.
  2. A Radiologist who is crucial for diagnosing fetal anomalies through imaging.
  3. A Paediatrician who offers insights into the potential viability and health of the fetus.
  4. Members nominated by state government in official Gazette

 

These experts collectively evaluate the condition to ensure a medically sound decision. However, the board does not include a legal advisor, as their role is primarily medical, focusing on the health aspects rather than legal counsel.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The Medical Board for MTP cases beyond 24 weeks includes an Obstetrician-Gynaecologist, Radiologist, and Paediatrician but does not include a legal advisor.

questions.text: Which of the following is called as Australia antigen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HBsAg

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) is also known as the Australia antigen. It is called so because it was first isolated from the serum of an Australian person.

 

Sera from hepatitis B patients when observed under an electron microscope show three types of particles:

 

  • A spherical particle: 22nm, most abundant, contains only HBsAg.
  • Filamentous or tubular particle: 22m, contains only HBsAg.
  • A double-walled spherical structure: 42m diameter, is the complete Hepatitis B virus. It was described by Dane and is called Dane particle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HBeAg: Incorrect, as HBeAg is a Hepatitis B envelope antigen associated with the virus's replication and infectivity but not known as the Australia antigen.

 

Option C. HBcAg: Incorrect, HBcAg or Hepatitis B core antigen is associated with the core of the virus but is not referred to as the Australia antigen.

 

Option D. HBV-DNA: Incorrect, this refers to the genetic material of the Hepatitis B virus itself and is not synonymous with the Australia antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HBsAg, also known as the Australia antigen, plays a pivotal role in the diagnosis and monitoring of Hepatitis B infection. Its presence in the blood typically indicates an active Hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having nocturnal cough for last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The presence of eosinophilia in an immunosuppressed patient with respiratory symptoms and BAL revealing rhabditiform larvae is suggestive of disseminated strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Strongyloidiasis:

 

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous. The transmission of infection occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine. The larvae moult twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

 

The life cycle of strongyloides is shown below.

 

 

It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms.

 

The term larva currens (meaning 'racing larvae') has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in immunodeficient individuals.

 

Larva currens is shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae of nonhuman species of nematodes that infect via the oral route.

 

Etiological agents causing visceral larva migrans:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Human nematode: Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Zoophilic nematode: Toxocara canis, toxocara cati, Angiostrongylus cantoniensis, Angiostrongylus costaricensis, Anisakis.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Non human nematode: Filarial species, Brugia pahangi, Brugia pate

 

Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
  • ﻿﻿Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
  • ﻿﻿Stool culture and serological tests are also done

 

Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma canium presents with creeping eruption. Cutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

Option B. Capillaria phillipinesis can also cause auto-infection. It commonly presents with severe diarrhea.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection presents as itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus)

 

Educational Objective

 

In patients presenting with respiratory symptoms and eosinophilia, especially those who are immunocompromised, strongyloidiasis should be considered. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent the severe outcomes associated with hyperinfection. Treatment typically involves antiparasitic medications such as ivermectin.

 

Autoinfection: - CHEST (Mnemonic)

 

  1. Cryptosporidium parvum
  2. H. nana larva
  3. Enterobius vermicularis
  4. Strongyloides
  5. Taenia solium

questions.text: Which receptor plays a crucial role in glucose uptake by skeletal muscles?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GLUT 4

 

Explanation

 

GLUT 4 is the glucose transporter responsible for insulin-stimulated glucose uptake in skeletal muscles, as well as in cardiac muscles and adipose tissues. Upon insulin binding, GLUT 4 translocates to the cell membrane, allowing glucose to enter the cells and be utilized for energy or stored as glycogen. This process is crucial for maintaining blood glucose levels postprandially (after meals).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GLUT 1: GLUT 1 is involved in basal glucose uptake and is widely distributed in tissues such as the brain, placenta, kidneys, and red blood cells.

 

Option B. GLUT 2: GLUT 2 is found in the liver, ancreas, intestines, and kidneys, playing a role in glucose absorption, glycogen formation, insulin secretion, and reabsorption processes.

 

Option C. GLUT 3: GLUT 3, similar to GLUT 1, is involved in basal glucose uptake and is primarily located in the brain, placenta, and kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT Transporters

questions.text: Identify the type of drain: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Closed suction drain

 

The drain shown in the image is a Romovac drain, which is a type of closed suction drain. Closed suction drains are used to remove fluids from a surgical site while maintaining a closed system, preventing contamination and infection. These drains have a bulb or collection reservoir that creates a negative pressure vacuum when compressed, allowing for continuous drainage of fluids from the wound site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open drain: These drains, like Penrose drains, are open systems where fluids drain passively onto a dressing or into a container, which increases the risk of infection due to exposure to the external environment.

 

Option B. Semi-open drain: These drains are a hybrid between open and closed systems, but are not as commonly used as purely open or closed systems.

 

Option D. Penrose drain: This is a type of open drain that allows passive drainage of fluids into the surrounding dressings. It is not connected to any suction mechanism or collection container.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Romovac drain is a closed suction drain that uses a vacuum system to actively remove fluids from a surgical site, reducing the risk of infection and aiding in the healing process.

questions.text: A 24y woman presents with suspected ovarian torsion. What is the investigation of choice? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ultrasound + Color Doppler

 

Ultrasound combined with Color Doppler is the investigation of choice for suspected ovarian torsion.

 

 

This combination is highly effective in identifying the condition. When a patient presents with symptoms of severe abdominal pain, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting, which is not relieved by analgesics, ovarian torsion should be considered, particularly if an adnexal mass is present. On the ultrasound with Color Doppler, the characteristic "whirlpool sign" can be observed, indicating twisted ovarian vessels and confirming the diagnosis.

 

The use of Color Doppler helps in assessing the blood flow to the ovary. In cases of torsion, blood flow may be absent, leading to ovarian ischemia. A laparoscopy can further confirm the diagnosis, revealing a twisted ovarian pedicle and a necrotic ovary if the torsion is prolonged. Treatment involves laparoscopic detorsion, where the twisted ovary is untwisted. If blood flow returns, a cystectomy may be performed to remove any cysts. If the ovary remains necrotic, an ovariectomy may be necessary to remove the affected ovary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ultrasound + Xray: While an ultrasound is useful, an Xray does not provide additional value in diagnosing ovarian torsion. X-rays are not effective in visualizing soft tissues or blood flow.

 

Option C. Ultrasound + DSA: Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is more invasive and not typically used for diagnosing ovarian torsion. It is mainly used for detailed vascular imaging.

 

Option D. MRI: MRI can provide detailed images but is not the first-line investigation due to its higher cost and limited availability compared to ultrasound with Color Doppler.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation of choice for suspected ovarian torsion is an ultrasound combined with Color Doppler, which helps visualize the characteristic whirlpool sign and assess blood flow to the ovary.

questions.text: Which family member is responsible for transmission of the disease in mitochondrial inheritance? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mother

 

Mitochondrial inheritance follows a maternal pattern of transmission. This is because the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is exclusively transmitted from the mother to all her children. During fertilization, the sperm contributes its nuclear DNA but its mitochondria are destroyed, so all mitochondria in the zygote come from the egg. This results in what is known as maternal inheritance, where diseases caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA are transmitted only through the mother.

 

  • Examples
    • MELAS → Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, Stroke
    • Leigh's Disease
    • NARP SYNDROME → Neuropathy, Ataxia, Retinitis Pigmentosal
    • Leber's Optic Neuropathy
  • Mitochondrial DNA is present in ovum & not in sperms

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grandfather (maternal): Incorrect. Though the maternal grandfather carries mitochondrial DNA, he cannot transmit it to his grandchildren. His daughters receive his nuclear DNA but their mitochondrial DNA comes from their mother (the maternal grandmother).

 

Option B. Grandfather (paternal): Incorrect. The paternal grandfather's mitochondrial DNA is not transmitted to his son, and consequently not to his grandchildren.

 

Option C. Father: Incorrect. Although the father contributes half of the nuclear DNA to the child, he does not contribute any mitochondrial DNA, as paternal mitochondria are destroyed after fertilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance follows a maternal transmission pattern in which only mothers can pass mitochondrial DNA mutations to their children. This occurs because all mitochondria in humans are inherited from the mother's egg cell, while paternal mitochondria are eliminated during fertilization.

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with hearing difficulty. On examination, the Rinne test is positive in the right ear and negative in the left ear. Weber's test shows lateralization to the right. Bone conduction is reduced in the left ear and normal in the right ear. What is the most likely interpretation of these findings? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

 

Explanation: 


The findings indicate severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear because:

 

  • Left ear shows Rinne negative test (false negative)
  • Weber lateralizes to right (better hearing) ear
  • Reduced bone conduction in left ear confirms inner ear pathology
  • This pattern occurs in severe unilateral SNHL where: 
    • Sound during bone conduction testing crosses to the normal ear (cross hearing)
    • Creates false impression of bone conduction better than air conduction
    • True pathology revealed by Weber test lateralizing away from affected ear
    • Reduced bone conduction confirms SNHL

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conductive hearing loss in the left ear

 

  • Would show true Rinne negative
  • Weber would lateralize to affected (left) ear
  • Bone conduction would be normal

 

Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear

 

  • Rinne would be positive in right ear (correct)
  • Weber would lateralize to left (unaffected) ear
  • Bone conduction would be reduced in right ear

 

Option C. Conductive hearing loss in the right ear

 

  • Rinne would be negative in right ear
  • Weber would lateralize to right ear
  • Bone conduction would be normal

 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative Rinne test with reduced bone conduction and Weber’s test lateralizing to the opposite ear suggests sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in the affected ear.

questions.text: Educating children on the importance of adopting a healthy lifestyle is an example of: [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Primordial prevention

 

  • Primordial prevention refers to actions taken to prevent the emergence or development of risk factors in populations where they have not yet appeared. Many adult health problems like obesity and hypertension have their early origins in childhood, as this is when lifestyles are formed through habits related to smoking, eating patterns, and physical exercise.
  • Educating children about healthy lifestyles specifically aims to discourage the adoption of harmful behaviors before risk factors develop. The main intervention method in primordial prevention is through individual and mass education.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary prevention: This involves action taken prior to the onset of disease when risk factors are already present. Primary prevention includes specific protection measures (like immunization) and health promotion but assumes risk factors may already exist.

 

Option B. Secondary prevention: This level focuses on early diagnosis and prompt treatment of disease that has already begun. It includes screening programs and case-finding activities to detect disease in its early stages.

 

Option C. Tertiary prevention: This addresses existing disease to limit complications, disability, and restore function. It includes rehabilitation and preventing further deterioration in patients with established conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primordial prevention represents the earliest intervention level in disease prevention, specifically targeting the formation of lifestyle habits in children before risk factors emerge, making it distinct from primary prevention which addresses existing risk factors.

questions.text:
The correct order of events of lactation in the puerperium are? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

 

  1. Lactogenesis
  2. Mammogenesis
  3. Galactopoiesis
  4. Galactokinesis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 1, 4, 3

 

Explanation:

 

The process of lactation involves several stages, each with specific physiological changes. Understanding these stages helps in comprehending the sequence of events that occur from the preparation of the breast during pregnancy to the maintenance of milk production.

 

2. Mammogenesis: This is the first stage, involving the development and growth of the mammary glands in preparation for lactation. It occurs during pregnancy when the breast tissue proliferates and differentiates under the influence of hormones such as estrogen and progesterone.

 

1. Lactogenesis: This stage refers to the initiation of milk production, which begins around the time of birth. Lactogenesis is divided into two phases:
 

  • Lactogenesis I: Occurs during pregnancy when the mammary gland is capable of producing some milk.
  • Lactogenesis II: Occurs postpartum when copious milk secretion begins, typically around 2-3 days after delivery, driven by the sudden drop in progesterone and the increase in prolactin.

 

4. Galactokinesis: This stage involves the ejection or movement of milk from the alveoli to the nipple. It is facilitated by the let-down reflex, which is triggered by the hormone oxytocin. Oxytocin causes the myoepithelial cells around the alveoli to contract, expelling the milk into the ducts and out through the nipple.

 

3. Galactopoiesis: This final stage refers to the maintenance of milk production. It is sustained by the regular removal of milk from the breast, either through breastfeeding or pumping, which maintains prolactin levels and keeps the milk supply ongoing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of events in lactation during the puerperium is: Mammogenesis (breast development), Lactogenesis (initiation of milk production), Galactokinesis (milk ejection), and Galactopoiesis (maintenance of milk production).

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a penicillin allergy presents with enterococcal endocarditis. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

Enterococci are gram-positive bacteria, and the first-line treatment for enterococcal infections is typically ampicillin. However, in patients with penicillin allergies, vancomycin is the preferred alternative. Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is effective against gram-positive bacteria, including enterococci. It works by inhibiting cell wall synthesis, leading to bacterial cell death.

 

 

  • Linezolid               
  • Tigecycline (Complicated Skin/Intra-abdominal Infections)
  • Daptomycin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aztreonam: This is a monobactam antibiotic that is primarily effective against gram-negative bacteria particularly in community-acquired pneumonia in ICU patients with a penicillin allergy, Aztreonam is the best choice.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: This is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic. While effective against some gram-positive bacteria, it is not the preferred choice for enterococcal infections, especially in patients with penicillin allergies due to the risk of cross-reactivity.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: This is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic. It would not be safe to use in a patient with a penicillin allergy due to the risk of a severe allergic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with penicillin allergies who have enterococcal infections, vancomycin is the preferred and safe alternative for treatment.

questions.text: If the RNA sequence is CAAGGU, what is the sequence of the template strand? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACCTTG

 

Explanation:

 

The given RNA sequence is CAAGGU. To determine the template strand sequence -

  1. Direction of RNA Sequence: The RNA sequence is provided without directions, but typically the sequence is read from 5' to 3'. Thus, the sequence is 5'-CAAGGU-3'.
  2. Non-Template Strand (Coding Strand) of DNA: The non-template strand of DNA has the same sequence as the RNA transcript except for the replacement of uracil (U) with thymine (T). Therefore, the non-template strand would be 5'-CAAGGT-3'.
  3. Template Strand of DNA: The template strand of DNA is complementary to the non-template strand. Complementarity means adenine (A) pairs with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) pairs with guanine (G). Therefore, the template strand, read in the 3' to 5' direction, would be:
    • C pairs with G
    • A pairs with T
    • A pairs with T
    • G pairs with C
    • G pairs with C
    • U (in RNA) pairs with A (in DNA, U replaced by T in RNA, so G pairs with C)

 

Therefore, the template strand is 3'-GTTAAC-5'. When we reverse the direction to match the 5' to 3' orientation given in the options, the sequence is ACCTTG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CAAGGT: This option is the sequence of the non-template (coding) strand of DNA, not the template strand.

 

Option B. GTTCCA: This option is not complementary to the RNA sequence.

 

Option D. TGGAAC: This option is incorrect as it does not match the complementary base pairing rules for the given RNA sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The template strand of DNA is complementary to the RNA sequence and the non-template strand, with the RNA sequence transcribed from the 5' to 3' direction of the non-template strand.

choices.text: The extent does not cross the wound margins
Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence
Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity
A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.text: A patient visits the clinic and presents with a raised and firm scar on their chest, which is larger than the original wound. The physician suspects a keloid scar and begins to explain the diagnosis and potential treatment options. Which of the following statements are true with regards to a keloid scar?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

 

A keloid scar forms due to an increase in the level of growth factors: This statement is true. Keloid scars are thought to develop due to an overproduction of growth factors, such as transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta), which stimulate the production of collagen and other extracellular matrix components. This abnormal healing response results in the excessive growth of scar tissue beyond the original wound margin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The extent does not cross the wound margins: This statement is not true. Keloid scars are characterized by an excessive growth of fibrous tissue beyond the original wound margin. They tend to be larger, more raised, and thicker than the original wound.

 

Option B. Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence: This statement is also not entirely true. While surgical removal of keloid scars can be effective, the risk of recurrence is high, and the scar may actually grow larger than the original one.

 

Option C. Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity: This statement is not true. Keloid scars are characterized by an overproduction of collagen, which leads to the thick and raised appearance of the scar. There may also be increased vascularity within the scar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keloid scars are caused by an overproduction of growth factors like TGF-β, leading to excessive collagen formation and scar tissue that extends beyond the wound margins.

questions.text: Which of the following mood stabilizers causes hepatitis ? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valproate

 

Valproate is known to cause hepatotoxicity, thus it is essential to monitor liver function tests regularly in patients taking valproate, especially during the initial months of therapy.

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Valproate, a commonly used mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder, is associated hepatitis. Regular monitoring of liver function tests is crucial in patients on valproate therapy to detect and manage potential liver damage early.

questions.text: A teacher presents with the following condition and hoarseness of the voice. Identify.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vocal nodule

 

Based on the description of the condition causing hoarseness in a teacher, a profession associated with voice strain, the most likely diagnosis is Vocal nodule.

 

Vocal nodules are bilateral, benign growths that typically occur at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords. They are often a result of vocal strain or overuse and present with a hoarse voice. The nodules are usually symmetrical and look like small bumps on either side of the vocal cords.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal carcinoma usually presents as an irregular, often unilateral growth on the vocal cord, and it can cause hoarseness. The lesion may have an irregular surface and can vary in coloration from the surrounding tissue. It is typically associated with risk factors like smoking and alcohol use.

 

Option C. Reinke’s edema is characterized by the swelling of the vocal cords due to fluid accumulation in Reinke's space (the layer of the vocal cord). The cords appear swollen and may take on a polypoid appearance, often associated with a lower-pitched, hoarse voice. Smoking is a common risk factor.

 

Option D. Vocal polyps are usually unilateral and can vary in size. They are often the result of acute vocal trauma or misuse. Polyps can cause hoarseness and have a soft, fluid-filled appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal nodules are benign, symmetrical lesions typically located at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords, often resulting from chronic vocal strain, and present with symptoms of hoarseness.

choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

 

The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression located on the lateral aspect of the wrist and the base of the thumb. When the thumb is extended, this depression becomes more pronounced. The lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box is formed by extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus.
