When you extend and abduct the thumb, you can typically feel these tendons, especially the abductor pollicis longus, become taut along the lateral border of the wrist, outlining the snuffbox.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. It extends the thumb's distal phalanx. The abductor pollicis brevis is a muscle of the thenar eminence and doesn't directly contribute to the boundaries of the anatomical snuffbox. Its tendon is not found in this region; instead, it inserts into the base of the thumb's proximal phalanx.

 

Option C. Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis: As already mentioned, the extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. The extensor pollicis brevis, in conjunction with the abductor pollicis longus, forms the lateral boundary. However, they don't together form just one boundary of the snuffbox.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis longus contributes to the lateral boundary of the snuffbox, as mentioned above. The abductor pollicis brevis, on the other hand, doesn't form any part of the snuffbox boundaries.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following cannot cross the placenta? (NEET PG 2018)

 

  1. Iron
  2. Albumin
  3. Immunoglobulin M
  4. Immunoglobulin G
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3

 

High molecular weight substances such as proteins (e.g., albumin, IgM, IgA) cannot cross the placenta.

 

Other Options:

 

1: Iron can cross the placenta via active transport mechanisms, making this option incorrect.

 

4: Immunoglobulin G (IgG) can cross the placenta through endocytosis and exocytosis mechanisms, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High molecular weight substances such as albumin and Immunoglobulin M (IgM) cannot cross the placenta.

questions.text: Rickets occurs due to deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin D

 

  • Rickets is a skeletal disorder that results from a deficiency of Vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. 
  • The primary cause of rickets is a lack of Vitamin D, which is essential for the absorption of calcium and phosphate in the body. 
  • Without adequate Vitamin D, bones can become soft and weak.
  • Key features of rickets include:
    • Cupping: The metaphyseal ends of bones become cup-shaped.
    • Splaying: An increase in the width of the metaphyseal ends.
    • Flaring: The ends of the bones point outward.

 

 

  • These characteristics are critical diagnostic features of rickets and help differentiate it from other bone disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to issues like night blindness and impaired immunity.

 

Option B. Vitamin B: B vitamins are crucial for energy production and neurological function. 

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, which presents with symptoms like bleeding gums and joint pain. In vitamin C deficiency, the bony ends appear more white on radiographs (Whitening).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rickets is primarily caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D, which leads to characteristic bone deformities such as cupping, splaying, and flaring of the metaphyseal ends.

questions.text: Identify the hemorrhage shown in the given image. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subdural hemorrhage

 

Subdural hemorrhages occur beneath the dura mater but outside the brain parenchyma, between the dura and the arachnoid layers. They typically appear as crescent-shaped hyperdense areas on CT scans, conforming to the brain surface and often crossing suture lines, unlike extradural hemorrhages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Hemorrhage (Epidural Hemorrhage): This type of hemorrhage occurs between the inner surface of the skull and the dura mater. On imaging, it usually appears as a lens-shaped (biconvex) hyperdense area that does not cross suture lines due to the attachment of the dura to the sutures.

 

Option B. Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage: This refers to bleeding within the brain tissue itself. On CT scans, intraparenchymal hemorrhages appear as irregular or rounded hyperdense areas within the brain parenchyma. They are often surrounded by a low-density area due to edema.

 

Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: This type of hemorrhage occurs in the subarachnoid space, between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater, covering the brain. It usually presents as a diffuse area of increased density in the spaces around the brain, particularly visible in the sulci and cisterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subdural hemorrhages, typically appear as crescent-shaped hyperdense areas on CT scans and in particular, require timely intervention to manage increased intracranial pressure and prevent permanent damage or death. They can present with symptoms ranging from mild headaches to severe neurological deficits, depending on the extent of the bleeding.

questions.text: A child presents with Patent Ductus Arteriosus, Cataract, and Salt & Pepper Retinopathy. This is suggestive of which intrauterine infection? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rubella

 

Explanation: 

 

Congenital Rubella Syndrome is characterized by the classic triad:

 

  • C: Cataract (nuclear pearly or lamellar)
  • H: Heart disease (Patent Ductus Arteriosus)
  • D: Deafness

 

Additional specific findings include:

 

  • Salt and pepper retinopathy
  • Micro-ophthalmia
  • Potential glaucoma
  • Characteristic nuclear pearly cataract

 

The syndrome results from maternal rubella infection during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester.
 

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Toxoplasma: Incorrect. While it can cause congenital infections, it does not match the specific triad described.

 

  • Toxoplasma triad: Intracranial calcification, chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus

 

Option B. Varicella: Incorrect. Does not cause the described constellation of symptoms.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus: Incorrect. While it can cause congenital infections, the specific triad is not consistent with CMV.

 

Educational Objective: 


Classic CHD (Cataract, Heart disease, Deafness) triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome, with salt and pepper retinopathy as a characteristic finding.

questions.text: Kinesin, dynein and myosin proteins are an example of? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Transport protein


Kinesin, dynein, and myosin are all examples of molecular motor proteins that play critical roles in cellular transport mechanisms.

 

  • Kinesin: This motor protein moves along microtubules in cells, transporting various cellular cargoes, such as organelles, vesicles, and proteins, from the center of the cell (soma) towards the periphery (axon terminal) in an anterograde direction.
  • Dynein: This motor protein also moves along microtubules but in the opposite direction, transporting cargo from the periphery back to the center of the cell in a retrograde direction.
  • Myosin: This motor protein interacts with actin filaments and is involved in a variety of cellular movements, including muscle contraction and intracellular cargo transport.

 

These proteins are not involved in cell membrane structure, adhesion of cell organelles, or forming intercellular junctions. Their primary function is to facilitate intracellular transport, making them key components of cellular logistics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell membrane protein: These are proteins that are part of or interact with the cell membrane, such as receptors and ion channels.

 

Option C. Cell organelle adherent protein: These proteins help maintain the structure and position of organelles within the cell. Ex: catenin and cadherin

 

Option D. Intercellular junctional protein: These are proteins that form connections between cells, such as connexins in gap junctions or occludins in tight junctions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kinesin, dynein, and myosin are transport proteins essential for intracellular cargo movement along cytoskeletal filaments.
